intro: Ipomoea hirtifolia, commonly known as the hairy morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its heart-shaped leaves and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink and violet. The plant is a vine that can climb using its tendrils, often reaching lengths of several meters. It blooms primarily in the spring and summer, producing flowers that open in the morning and close by midday. The hairy hirtifolia is adapted to moist, well-drained soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade.
